column1: #Summary1=(human1) This dictionary entry for the word 'trust' provides its etymology from Middle English 'trust' and Proto-Indo-European *deru- 'be firm', cognates such as Danish trøst, pronunciations like /trʌst/ and /trʊst/ and synonyms, antonyms, usage examples and definitions as a noun (e.g. 'confidence', 'hope'), senses in computing and law, and as a verb meaning to have faith or believe.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) This dictionary entry for 'trust' traces its etymology from Middle English and Germanic roots, provides IPA pronunciations, and defines it as a noun meaning confidence/reliance, a verb meaning to place confidence in someone/something, and an obsolete adjective meaning secure/faithful, with various legal and financial uses.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) This entry for the word 'trust' details its pronunciation /trʌst/, etymology tracing back to Middle English and Proto-Indo-European roots, meanings such as confidence, hope, and legal arrangements, usage as both noun and verb, related terms like faith and belief, and antonyms including distrust and mistrust.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The English word "trust" originates from Old English and Proto-Germanic roots, ultimately tracing back to Proto-Indo-European *deru-, with various meanings including confidence, protection, and reliance.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct) The entry defines "trust" in English, tracing its etymology from Old Norse to Proto-Indo-European, providing its various uses including confidence, hope, and legal obligations, with detailed pronunciations and synonyms.

#Text=Long considered a borrowing from Old Norse traust ( “ confidence , help , protection ” ) , itself from Proto - Germanic *traustą , but the root vocalism is incompatible , and now it 's considered a reflex of an unattested Old English *trust , from a rare zero - grade proto - Germanic variant of the same root also attested in Middle High German getrüste ( “ host ” ) .
#Text=Ultimately from Proto - Indo - European *deru- ( be firm , hard , solid ” ) .

#Text=Akin to Danish trøst ( “ comfort , solace ” ) , Saterland Frisian Traast ( “ comfort , solace ” ) , West Frisian treast ( “ comfort , solace ” ) , Dutch troost ( “ comfort , consolation ” ) , German Trost ( “ comfort , consolation ” ) , Gothic trausti ( trausti , “ alliance , pact ” ) .
#Text=Confidence in or reliance on some person or quality .
#Text=He needs to regain her trust if he is ever going to win her back .
#Text=Dependence upon something in the future ; hope .
#Text=Confidence in the future payment for goods or services supplied ; credit .
#Text=I was out of cash , but the landlady let me have it on trust .
#Text=That which is committed or entrusted ; something received in confidence ; a charge .
#Text=That upon which confidence is reposed ; ground of reliance ; hope .
#Text=The condition or obligation of one to whom anything is confided ; responsible charge or office .
#Text=The confidence vested in a person who has legal ownership of a property to manage for the benefit of another .
#Text=I put the house into my sister 's trust .

#Text=An arrangement whereby property or money is given to be held by a third party ( a trustee ) , on the basis that it will be managed for the benefit of , or eventually transferred to , a stated beneficiary ; for example , money to be given to a child when he or she reaches adulthood .
#Text=A group of businessmen or traders organised for mutual benefit to produce and distribute specific commodities or services , and managed by a central body of trustees .
#Text=Affirmation of the access rights of a user of a computer system .
#Text=( confidence in a person or quality ) belief , confidence , faith
#Text=trust ( third - person singular simple present trusts , present participle trusting , simple past and past participle trusted )
#Text=To place confidence in , to rely on , to confide in .
#Text=We can not trust anyone who deceives us .
#Text=To have faith in ; to rely on for continuing support or aid .
#Text=In God We Trust ( official US motto )
#Text=To give credence to ; to believe ; to credit .
#Text=To hope confidently ; to believe ( usually with a phrase or infinitive clause as the object )
#Text=I trust you have cleaned your room ?
#Text=to show confidence in a person by entrusting them with something .
#Text=To commit , as to one 's care ; to entrust .
#Text=To give credit to ; to sell to upon credit , or in confidence of future payment .
#Text=Merchants and manufacturers trust their customers annually with goods .
#Text=To rely on ( something ) , as though having trust ( on it ) .
#Text=Having lost the book , he had to trust to his memory for further details .
#Text=To have trust ; to be credulous ; to be won to confidence ; to confide .
#Text=To sell or deliver anything in reliance upon a promise of payment ; to give credit .
#Text=trust ( comparative more trust , superlative most trust )
